So first I want to deci define async and sync first communication just so that we're all on the same page So if it's
asynchronous communication is I send a message without expecting an immediate response So I might send one of my team
members a message about an upcoming project that I need them to work on or a PR that's been done and then I kind of
leave that I don't have any expectations We'll we'll there's more to that We'll cover that in a sec But that's the
general idea Synchronous or real time communication
is sort of the opposite of that I send a message My expectation is that they're going to start processing that
information and respond to me straight away which is likely what most of the
folks here are used to now even if you are working remotely in your company But

And this is what we've sort of come to know is the best way of working in this
area that makes the team really strong gets everyone to do their work but is importantly also focusing on our team

trust Uh I think this is essential really for async first communication as
well If your team's going to work from anywhere at any time there needs to be trust right the same as any kind of
healthy relationship Your teammates can trust that you'll do what you said you were going to do and that they'll do the
same in return when you ask that Now you have to assume kind of a healthy level
of trust And I kind of like this example from Toby Luki at Spotify of the trust
battery You have to kind of start at 50% trust right just by default And then all
your interactions are either hopefully going to charge that battery or worst case scenario discharge that battery But
we want to aim on how we can do that all the time How we can increase the trust battery
there One of the ways we found was setting before when I was given the example of like async I just send them a
message and walk off right one of the ways we found to help build trust because it starts to feel like oh are
they ignoring me or you know is there some is there a problem here but that's typically not the case right they're
just busy in their flow state So what we decided to help with that is have a maximum of 24 hours that we agree to
respond to a message And in that time you can think about it process the information and make sure that you're
giving a good response If you leave it sort of too much longer than that with all the time
zones then it can start to really kind of drag out Now that can even mean right you
stopped by that person or the message that they've sent you and said "Yep this is on my radar I will respond to you at
this point in time." And the important part there is to do that right because we're trying to build trust here in this
scenario Play around with this thing 24 hours works for where we are but you
might start at a more reasonable say eight hours and build on from there particularly as you start to find value
in that time that is uninterrupted But trust is a big topic
So there's an article here on how to build trust in remote workplaces that we'll run through this in sort of more
detail so that can help you with that And see a few phones in the air So I'll just pad this space
walking autonomy Uh you would have heard some of this talked about like if you went to Yo Kim's talk from Spotify how
autonomy enabled them to release one of the biggest features that they've had at Spotify And that's why I really like
this autonomy but responsibility forms an important part of that as well So now
you get to structure your day in this setup how you would like and gain autonomy right organize work around life
instead of the other way around which we sort of typically do now If you're a night owl and want to work in the
evening well that should be fine Uh if you need to stop during the day and you have an errand when it's quiet that
should also be fine right that shouldn't kind of impact anyone So how can we enable that level of autonomy while we
maintain the responsibility as well we split our teams up Again if you
s saw Yo Kim's talk this might sort of be resonating with you or or being kind of familiar but we split our teams up
into these little squads of workers So whatever their work that they have to do
be it a marketing initiative new emails landing pages whatever it is we take the people from the permanent functional
teams and we create cross functional teams that have the people in there that know how to do that work And a squad
like this can last a month or more just sort of depends on the level of work We've been playing around with three monthly squads at this point in time The
responsibility part comes into that within your squad So instead of daily
standups and the ceremonies that exist in some of these things which are impossible over time zones what we do is
have a weekly snippet So in there you'll talk about some of what you've done That can be useful but importantly what
you're going to get through in the week ahead and really important if there's any problems that have come up in that
time because if we know the problems then the team can sort of gather around that and try and address it right before
it becomes a big problem And this was an area that I sort of struggled
with when I was first starting async work I kept checking twist which is our tool but it doesn't fully matter

it helped sort of my health and well-being being able to kind of go to the gym or do something at 9:30 in the

Now because all of these conversations aren't happening in real time like we do with sync work one of the easiest ways
to avoid being a blocker is by adopting the idea of transparency by default Now if there's a document server
whatever it might be that your team needs access to it could be a long turnaround before that happens We've
been playing around with 24 hours right now this is true for hybrid teams as well or how do you make sure that those
working hybrid feel part of the team and not just at a sort of third party and
the decisions are made in the office and this is kind of how we level that playing field and keep everyone included
We avoid it by you know just make it as open as possible So if I wanted to I can access planning documents even financial
reports are sort of all in our thing and we can access it Now it's not everything right if there's sort of an issue that's
like a persontoerson kind of thing or HR information that stuff is still private
But outside of those things work-wise if I need to catch up on a thread progress of work or you get put into a project
you can catch up on all of this if all of it's open and available not in sort of email or
that Now if you're if you as an individual right some of the things that people ask me is as a if I'm not leading
how can I get this going and this is one of the ways that you can do that right make sure as much of your information
and work and what you're doing is as open as possible in the first place GitLab are a really good uh
example of kind of living this transparent by default life in their handbook which all of their
documentation is but importantly is public as well So they're really transparent in there Now that kind of
leads us nicely into everyone being a writer If writing becomes the core of
how you communicate at this point in time then you know it it can't sort of
be understated how important the sort of clear concise and what is it clear
concise and engaging communication is when we sort of switch to this style of
working documentation when you're doing this starts to become basically automatic
right it's the the part we least like doing but if we're writing by default then these things start to become
automatic and we don't need to focus on it as much as what we otherwise would need to Now when a decision is required
typically we'll write it in our communication tool and do that or if the conversation has happened in real time
then we need to bring that back into whatever that sort of tool is that we're using for it
What I sort of like about this outside of the writing is how inclusive async first communication starts to
become Being the loudest person in the room at this point isn't like a prerequisite to getting your point of
view across at this when you're doing this You've got that 24 hours to think about it Make sure that you say what you

of style of working can really help alleviate those problems right they're not going to think about that They've got time to do it And you know a
downside of this is that the decisions will take longer right definitely But

appropriate And it's a really great way to sort of rubber duck yourself as well There's been many times where I've kind
of been having a problem and I start to write down all of the issues and things
that I'm experiencing in there and in doing so kind of get myself to the point
of realization and go oh here's something that I've missed or even if you don't reach that point what you can
